title: SIM Swap Banking Fraud - Mumbai 2023
summary: Attackers obtained duplicate SIM cards to intercept OTPs and drain bank accounts, affecting over 50 victims.
details:
In January 2023, a sophisticated fraud ring in Mumbai executed SIM swap attacks targeting high-net-worth individuals. The attackers used social engineering to obtain personal information from social media profiles, then convinced telecom employees to issue duplicate SIM cards by presenting fake identity documents.

Once they controlled victims' phone numbers, they intercepted one-time passwords (OTPs) used for two-factor authentication. This allowed them to access bank accounts, transfer funds, and make unauthorized purchases. The fraud went undetected for weeks as victims didn't immediately notice their SIM cards had been deactivated.

The case broke when multiple victims reported simultaneous account drains. Investigation revealed the attackers had insider help at telecom providers and used money mules to withdraw cash quickly. Total losses exceeded ₹2.5 crore before the ring was busted.
impact: ₹2.5 crore stolen from 50+ victims. Several victims lost their life savings. The case highlighted vulnerabilities in telecom provider security procedures and the risks of SMS-based two-factor authentication.
laws: Indian Penal Code Section 420 (cheating), Section 468 (forgery), Section 120B (criminal conspiracy). Information Technology Act Section 66C (identity theft), Section 66D (cheating by personation using computer resources). Indian Telegraph Act violations. Maximum penalty: 7 years imprisonment plus fines.
prevention: Never share OTPs with anyone - legitimate organizations never ask for them
Enable additional security features beyond SMS 2FA (biometrics, app-based authentication)
Set up transaction alerts for all banking activities
Use authenticator apps instead of SMS when possible
Register for Do Not Disturb (DND) to reduce phishing calls
Regularly monitor bank statements and credit reports
Limit personal information shared on social media
Set up SIM card PIN lock (most people don't know this exists)
immediate_actions: Immediately contact your mobile carrier if your SIM suddenly stops working
Block your bank accounts and credit cards instantly
File complaint at cybercrime.gov.in and local police station
Change all banking passwords using a different device
Request transaction history from bank to identify fraudulent transfers
Contact your bank's fraud department for possible reversal
Notify all contacts that your number may be compromised
Check credit score for unauthorized accounts or loans

title: Fake KYC Update Phishing - Delhi 2024
summary: Mass phishing campaign tricked bank customers into providing credentials on fake KYC update websites, compromising thousands of accounts.
details:
In March 2024, a large-scale phishing operation targeted customers of major Indian banks. Victims received professional-looking SMS messages claiming their KYC (Know Your Customer) information would expire within 24 hours, requiring immediate updating to avoid account suspension.

The messages contained links to convincing replica websites of major banks (SBI, HDFC, ICICI). These fake sites were hosted on domains similar to legitimate ones (e.g., sbi-kyc-update.com instead of onlinesbi.com). The sites collected:
- Full name and address
- PAN card and Aadhaar numbers
- Bank account numbers
- Credit/debit card details including CVV
- Internet banking username and password
- OTPs entered in real-time

Attackers used collected information immediately to transfer funds, make purchases, and create new payment accounts. The sophisticated operation included a fake customer service number that reassured suspicious victims.

The scam was discovered when banks noticed unusual patterns of account access from foreign IP addresses. By then, over 3,000 accounts had been compromised with total losses exceeding ₹15 crore.
impact: Over ₹15 crore stolen from 3,000+ victims across India. Many victims were elderly customers unfamiliar with digital banking security. Banks faced reputation damage and increased fraud prevention costs. Several victims faced financial hardship from drained savings accounts.
laws: Information Technology Act Section 66C (identity theft), Section 66D (cheating by personation), Section 43 (unauthorized access). Indian Penal Code Section 420 (cheating), Section 415 (fraud). Banking Regulation Act violations. Imprisonment up to 3-7 years plus substantial fines.
prevention: Banks NEVER ask customers to update KYC through SMS links
Always visit official bank websites by typing URL directly, never through links
Verify sender phone numbers against official bank contact information
Look for HTTPS and proper SSL certificates on banking websites
Never provide CVV or OTP to anyone - banks don't ask for these
Be suspicious of urgent messages creating artificial time pressure
Enable transaction notifications on mobile apps
Register phone number with bank for official communications only
immediate_actions: If you entered details, contact your bank immediately to freeze accounts
Block all debit/credit cards associated with the account
Change internet banking passwords immediately using official channels
Report the phishing website to cybercrime.gov.in with screenshots
File FIR at local cyber crime police station
Monitor accounts closely for 90 days for suspicious activity
Request new debit/credit cards with different numbers
Place fraud alert on credit reports
Save all evidence: SMS, emails, website screenshots, transaction records

title: Ransomware Attack on Hospital - Bangalore 2023
summary: A major private hospital's entire digital infrastructure was encrypted by ransomware, disrupting patient care and demanding $100,000 for decryption.
details:
In August 2023, a 500-bed private hospital in Bangalore suffered a devastating ransomware attack that encrypted patient records, imaging systems, laboratory databases, and administrative networks. The attack occurred through a phishing email sent to an administrative employee who downloaded what appeared to be a patient referral document.

Once inside the network, the ransomware spread rapidly through networked systems, encrypting:
- Electronic Health Records (EHR) for 50,000+ patients
- X-ray, MRI, and CT scan images
- Laboratory test results and reports
- Billing and insurance systems
- Pharmacy inventory and prescription records
- Appointment scheduling systems

Within hours, the hospital could not access patient histories, view diagnostic images, or process new admissions. Emergency services were diverted to other hospitals. Surgical procedures were postponed. Doctors reverted to paper records and manual processes.

The ransomware displayed a message demanding $100,000 in Bitcoin within 72 hours, threatening to publish sensitive patient data on the dark web if unpaid. The hospital had outdated backups that were also partially encrypted.

After involving cybersecurity experts and law enforcement, the hospital chose not to pay. Recovery took three weeks, cost over ₹2 crore, and required rebuilding systems from scratch. Some patient data was permanently lost. No arrests were made as attackers operated from overseas.
impact: Three weeks of operational disruption. ₹2+ crore recovery costs. Permanent loss of some patient records. Reputation damage and patient trust erosion. Potential regulatory penalties for data breach. Several patients had treatment delays with health consequences.
laws: Information Technology Act Section 66 (computer-related offenses), Section 43 (damage to computer systems). Indian Penal Code Section 384 (extortion), Section 506 (criminal intimidation). Patient data breach falls under IT Act data protection provisions and upcoming Digital Personal Data Protection Act. International cooperation required for overseas attackers.
prevention: Implement comprehensive backup strategy with offsite/offline copies
Regular security awareness training for all staff
Network segmentation to isolate critical systems
Email filtering with attachment scanning
Regular security audits and penetration testing
Maintain updated antivirus and endpoint protection
Disable macros in email attachments by default
Implement strict access controls and least privilege principle
Have incident response plan with regular drills
Keep all systems patched and updated
Consider cyber insurance for healthcare facilities
immediate_actions: Immediately disconnect infected systems from network
Do not shut down infected computers (may lose decryption possibility)
Isolate backup systems to prevent encryption
Activate incident response team and document everything
Report to CERT-In and cybercrime authorities immediately
Notify patients of potential data breach as required by law
Consult cybersecurity experts before making any decisions
Do not pay ransom (generally) - no guarantee of decryption, funds criminals
Preserve evidence for investigation
Activate business continuity plan and manual procedures
Communicate transparently with staff, patients, and media

title: ATM Skimming and Malware - Pan-India Network 2024
summary: International criminal network installed skimmers and malware on ATMs across India, stealing card data and PINs from thousands of customers.
details:
Between January and June 2024, law enforcement uncovered a sophisticated ATM fraud operation spanning 12 Indian states. The operation combined physical skimming devices with malware installed on ATM systems.

The Attack Method:
1. Physical access: Attackers posed as technicians to access ATM machines
2. Skimmer installation: Devices placed over card readers captured magnetic stripe data
3. Hidden cameras: Recorded PIN entries from various angles
4. ATM malware: Jackpotting software installed on some machines to directly dispense cash
5. Data harvesting: Stolen card data transmitted via cellular networks to overseas servers
6. Card cloning: Information used to create duplicate cards
7. Cash withdrawal: Mules simultaneously withdrew money from multiple ATMs across the country

The operation was highly organized with distinct roles:
- Technical team installing devices
- Data processors creating cloned cards
- Money mules making withdrawals
- International coordinators managing operations

The fraud was detected when multiple banks noticed unusual patterns: hundreds of cards used at ATMs far from their usual locations within minutes of each other. Forensic analysis revealed skimmers on 200+ ATMs across India.

Total estimated losses exceeded ₹50 crore affecting over 10,000 customers. International cooperation led to arrests in Romania, Bulgaria, and India, though the primary organizers remained at large.
impact: ₹50+ crore in losses across multiple banks. 10,000+ customers affected. Banks incurred costs for ATM security upgrades, card replacements, and fraud investigations. Customer trust in ATM safety declined. Increased insurance premiums for banks.
laws: Information Technology Act Section 66C (identity theft), Section 43 (unauthorized access to computer resources). Indian Penal Code Section 420 (cheating), Section 120B (criminal conspiracy), Section 379 (theft). Payment and Settlement Systems Act violations. International crime requiring cooperation through Interpol and bilateral treaties.
prevention: Inspect ATMs for unusual devices before use (check card slot, keypad, and surrounding areas)
Cover PIN entry with your hand or body
Use ATMs inside bank branches rather than standalone machines when possible
Enable transaction alerts for real-time monitoring
Set daily withdrawal and transaction limits
Check for loose, misaligned, or oddly colored card readers
Be suspicious if card is difficult to insert or gets stuck
Use chip-and-PIN rather than magnetic stripe when possible
Regularly review bank statements for unauthorized transactions
Avoid ATMs in isolated or poorly lit locations
Consider using contactless payments or mobile banking instead
immediate_actions: Report unauthorized transactions to bank within 3 days for zero liability
Request immediate card blocking and replacement
File complaint at cybercrime.gov.in with transaction details
Change ATM PIN immediately using secure methods
Review all accounts for suspicious activity
Request bank to investigate the specific ATM used
Keep detailed records: dates, times, ATM locations, amounts
Monitor account closely for next 90 days
Consider temporarily freezing card for online transactions
Report physical skimmers to bank and police if discovered
Request refund through bank's fraud protection policy
